channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: UK loses appeal to deport radical cleric
item.description: The British government on Wednesday lost another round in its long-running attempt to deport radical cleric Abu Qatada to Jordan.

item.title: 52 Taliban members killed in one day
item.description: A blitz of attacks across Afghanistan led to the deaths of 52 armed Taliban members in the past day, the Ministry of Interior said Wednesday.

item.title: Pope Francis shuns luxury papal home
item.description: Pope Francis has decided not to move into the papal apartment used by Benedict XVI and others before him, preferring instead to stay in a simple suite at a Vatican hotel, a Vatican spokesman said.

item.title: Bones of England's King Alfred found?
item.description: Archaeologists dug up an unmarked grave in a quiet English churchyard in search of remains of King Alfred the Great, a ninth century monarch credited with fending off the Vikings.

item.title: U.N. chief wants Mali peacekeepers
item.description: Up to 11,200 peacekeeping troops could maintain stability in Mali under a new U.N. proposal.

item.title: Two killed in Iraqi restaurant blast
item.description: At least two people were killed Wednesday when a hidden explosive device detonated inside a restaurant, Baghdad police said.

item.title: Boy, 4, found with decomposing body
item.description: A 4-year-old boy was found alive but malnourished in a Union, New Jersey, apartment where police also discovered the decomposing body of a woman.

item.title: Petraeus apologizes for affair
item.description: In a rare public appearance since admitting to an extramarital affair, retired Gen. David Petraeus apologized Tuesday night for the scandal that led to his resignation as head of the CIA last year.

item.title: Looters roam Central African Republic
item.description: Days after a coup plunged the Central African Republic into chaos, looters roamed the streets of the capital, robbing hospitals and preventing fearful residents from seeking treatment.

item.title: More curfews after Myanmar attacks
item.description: As sectarian tensions continue to boil in central Myanmar, authorities have imposed curfews in more towns in an attempt to stop groups of Buddhists from setting fire to mosques and Muslims' homes.

item.title: FAA: Electronics may get OK for landing
item.description: Tablets, laptops, e-readers, smartphones. They keep us plugged in everywhere we go, except when we're on a plane.

item.title: FBI probes 'suspicious' cruise death
item.description: The FBI is investigating the mysterious death of a 64-year-old woman aboard a Royal Caribbean cruise ship.

item.title: Elephants slaughtered in Cameroon
item.description: Heavily armed poachers recently killed nearly 40 endangered forest elephants for their ivory in two national parks, officials in Cameroon said Tuesday, the latest in a string of slaughters of the animals in Central Africa.

item.title: Global pool of AAA bonds shrinks 60%
item.description: The global pool of government bonds with triple A status from the three main rating agencies, the bedrock of the financial -system, has shrunk more than 60 per cent since the financial crisis triggered a wave of downgrades across the advanced economies.

item.title: U.S., Mexico tie in World Cup qualifier
item.description: In a World Cup qualifier featuring heated regional rivals, the United States and Mexico tied 0-0 at Mexico City on Tuesday night.

item.title: Neighbor accuses Bieber of 'battery'
item.description: Justin Bieber's neighbor accused the singer of "battery and threats" after a confrontation outside his Calabasas, California, home on Tuesday morning, a law enforcement spokesman said.

item.title: Dionne Warwick files for bankruptcy
item.description: Dionne Warwick, one of the most recognizable pop voices of the 1960s, filed for bankruptcy last week citing more than $10 million in tax debt dating back to 1991.

item.title: Did we learn nothing from Newtown?
item.description: Many people thought that the massacre of 20 young school children and six educators by a gunman wielding an assault weapon would change the terms of the debate over firearms regulation.

item.title: How gay rights went mainstream
item.description: Whatever the Supreme Court decides, support for allowing same-sex marriage has become a majority view in the U.S.

item.title: For Tiger, winning is everything
item.description: Roxanne Jones says Nike's ad about Tiger Woods makes perfect sense.

item.title: Cyprus: Design of future bailouts?
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest explains the Cyprus bailout template.

item.title: North Korea cuts off military hotline to South Korea
item.description: North Korea is to cut off a key military link with South Korea amid high tensions between the two sides, claiming it is not needed "where a war may break out any moment."

item.title: N. Korea military 'prepares' for strikes
item.description: North Korea says it is placing military units on combat-ready status "to prepare for possible strikes against the U.S. mainland, Hawaii and Guam" and U.S. Pacific bases.

item.title: Threats to U.S.
item.description: Erin Burnett talks to CNN's Matthew Chance about North Korea threats of attack on islands like the island of Yeonpyeong.

item.title: Five things to know: N. Korea threats
item.description: Video propaganda showing the White House and Congress being blown up. Talk of hitting U.S. bases in the Pacific. The renunciation of a 60-year-old armistice that has kept the tenuous peace on the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: Photos: Kim Jong Un and the military
Timeline: War of words
item.description: North Korea upped the ante Tuesday in its war of words, threatening to target South Korea and U.S. military bases.

item.title: Knox vows to fight on as retrial called
item.description: Italian Supreme Court judges rule Amanda Knox and her ex-boyfriend should stand trial again for the 2007 murder of her former roommate Meredith Kercher in Italy.

item.title: Knox's lawyer 'we're ready to fight'
item.description: Amanda Knox's lawyer, Carlo Dalla Vedova, reacts to the Italian Supreme Court ruling that she should stand trial again.

item.title: Experts disagree over extradition
item.description: Experts disagreed Tuesday over whether Amanda Knox is likely to be extradited to Italy, where the country's highest criminal court overturned her acquittal and that of her former boyfriend in the 2007 killing of her roommate, Meredith Kercher.

item.title: Profile: Amanda Knox
item.description: Since her release from an Italian prison, Amanda Knox has been trying to keep out of the public eye back in her hometown, Seattle.

item.title: U.S. Supreme Court in uncharted waters
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court is set for a second day of arguments on the constitutionality of a federal law that defines marriage as only between a man and a woman.

item.title: Justices hint at diverging views
item.description: As the U.S. Supreme Court began hearing arguments over same-sex marriage, the justices seem "deeply divided." The court could alter how the law treats marriage.

item.title: Supreme Court appears 'fractured'
item.description: CNN's Erin Burnett talks to CNN Senior Legal Analyst about the Supreme Court Justices debating same-sex marriage.

item.title: 5 key issues
item.description: The question of same-sex marriage went before the U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday in the first of two oral arguments this week on separate appeals.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: Scientists close in on invisibility cloak
item.description: Some scientists seem to take their cues from science fiction or fantasy novels.

item.title: Dirty cash: What's in your wallet?
item.description: Research reveals the extent of bacteria on bills and coins. CNN's Richard Quest reports.

item.title: Is Africa much richer than we think?
item.description: Many African economies are much richer than we think, but bad statistics mean we know little about poverty and wealth in Africa, says one expert.

item.title: Viagra: The little blue pill that could
item.description: Fifteen years ago, men who were suffering from impotence received a beacon of hope in the form of a little blue pill.

item.title: Experts disagree over Knox extradition
item.description: Experts disagreed Tuesday over whether Amanda Knox is likely to be extradited to Italy, where the country's highest criminal court overturned her acquittal and that of her former boyfriend in the 2007 killing of her roommate, Meredith Kercher.

item.title: Made in Mexico: Luxury sports car
item.description: CNN's Nick Parker reports on Mexico's luxury car market.

item.title: Church's 'strip for me' billboard
item.description: An Alabama church says its controversial billboard is doing it's job, getting people talking. WBRC has more.

item.title: Hero Chihuahua takes on pit bull
item.description: A Chihuahua showed big courage when he came to the rescue of a little girl being attacked by a pit bull. CTV reports.

item.title: Long on lyrics, short on rehab
item.description: Is there a stigma about discussing coming clean in a musical genre that many feel has promoted drug use?

item.title: Rapping about drugs
item.description: Is there a stigma about coming clean in a music g

item.title: Playing Hong Kong's dangerous game
item.description: Would you pay to be handcuffed and locked in a dark room? Or blindfolded and shut in a prison cell with friends?

item.title: Video gaming in the real world
item.description: CNN's Patricia Wu and Andrew Stevens try out Hong Kong's latest entertainment hot spot and go gaming in real life.

item.title: China's Michelle Obama?
item.description: Wives of Chinese leaders usually stand in the background, but Peng Liyuan is no ordinary First Lady.

item.title: Would Syria use chemical weapons?
item.description: Few munitions evoke as much fear as chemical weapons, which, unlike nuclear weapons, are relatively inexpensive to develop and stockpile. So does Syria have them and, if so, would it put them to use?

item.title: Should Beckham have moved to PSG?
item.description: Catch all the CNN FC off-field talk, as Pedro Pinto, Ian Wright and others discuss Becks' career as well as racism in football.

item.title: Nadal doing nada: Star unwinds in Mexico
item.description: Don Riddell joins tennis star Rafa Nadal as he unwinds between tournaments in Mexico. Airs in full Thurs 21, 1730 CET

item.title: Plane campaign: Does sexy sell seats?
item.description: Images of bikini-clad women in Thailand posing suggestively in an online ad for a local airline inflamed passions -- both positive and negative -- earlier this year.

item.title: What Mick Jagger is teaching his children
item.description: Ruben Navarrette says being a good parent is about teaching adult children to stand on their own two feet.

item.title: When Princess Diana and Travolta danced
item.description: Sumptuous velvet, delicate sequins, intricate beading: They are dresses fit for a princess -- Princess Diana, that is -- and if you've got a big pocketbook (with a designer label, naturally), they could have been yours.

item.title: Decision-making robots -- here to help
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Will winning help Tiger's troubles?
item.description: As prodigal golfer Tiger Woods resumes the world's No. 1 ranking, his chief sponsor, Nike, unveiled a slogan Tuesday that provokes robust debate on what is redemption and has Woods attained it.

item.title: Friendly unites Iraq against Syria
item.description: Throngs of jubilant Iraqis, some so happy they wept, gathered early Tuesday at Baghdad's al-Shaab Stadium for the country's first international soccer match in years.

item.title: Island close to N. Korea threat
item.description: It may be easy to dismiss North Korea's threats as bluster, unless you're on this South Korean island, which was shelled in 2010.

item.title: Packing up to leave Afghanistan
item.description: The U.S. military prepares to end its combat mission in Afghanistan, as CNN's Anna Coren reports.

item.title: Female director for Secret Service?
item.description: President Obama will appoint Julia Pierson as the first female director of the Secret Service, a White House official told CNN on Tuesday.

item.title: Tracking your GPS 'fingerprint'
item.description: Can you be identified only by where you take your phone? Yes, according to a new study.

item.title: Why do so few Indians pay tax?
item.description: Fewer than three percent of Indians pay income tax. CNN's Mallika Kapur reports on what that means to India's future.

item.title: Michael Phelps' golf growing pains
item.description: As a swimmer, his countless hours of training paid off handsomely -- earning him a record 18 Olympic gold medals.

item.title: Spain's coach: I've been lucky
item.description: Spain's World Cup-winning coach Vicente Del Bosque reveals the secret of his success ahead of a key match.

item.title: First-class vs. business: Worth it?
item.description: Firsters don't just get bigger seats and better bathrooms -- limo service and express security lines can be part of the deal

item.title: Hollywood targets White House
item.description: Several movies put the "President" in peril and target the White House. CNN's Jake Tapper reports.

item.title: Why Apple wants to track you inside
item.description: Sure, the GPS on your phone or dedicated device can get you from Point A to Point B on the interstate, frustrating "Calibrating ... calibrating ..." moments aside.

item.title: Burning Passover's 'garbage'
item.description: In the ultra-Orthodox Jerusalem neighborhood of Mea Sha'ari, Joe Liebovitz explains why Jews burn bread for Passover.

item.title: U.S. lowers bar for N. Korea attack
item.description: A new agreement formalizes a joint U.S.-South Korean response to even small-scale attacks from North Korea.

item.title: Can FB help us see future?
item.description: Social media sites have become the global equivalent of the office watercooler, but could the buzz they generate be analyzed to predict real-world outcomes? Economist Noreena Hertz thinks so.

item.title: Coral reefs: Pulse of the oceans
item.description: CNN special correspondent Philippe Cousteau explains the impact of climate change on the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Teacher's death sparks school protection calls
item.description: Shahnaz Nazli, a teacher and mother-of-one, was on her way to work at a girls' school in Pakistan when she was gunned down by two men on a bike.

item.title: Iraq War: Should Bush, Blair be charged?
item.description: It is time for Bush and Blair to be thoroughly investigated for the 'tawdry tale' of the Iraq War, UK lawyer says.

item.title: Photographer shares memories
item.description: Ten years since the U.S. invasion, photojournalist Peter Turnley shares his collection of images from the Iraq War.

item.title: 'I'd rather he was dead than arrested'
item.description: Family and friends focus on one goal: Identify the individual who can help free him in return for money.

item.title: Pondering a nightmare: War in Korea
item.description: It's Asia's nightmare scenario: War breaking out on the Korean peninsula. While experts say its unlikely, Pyongyang's bellicose rhetoric has military strategists examining what might happen if the unthinkable occurs.

item.title: Who really killed Osama bin Laden?
item.description: A member of the secretive SEAL Team 6 tells CNN a previous account of Osama bin Laden's shooting is wrong.

item.title: Examining the evidence
item.description: CNN's Chris Lawrence looks into an account by a former Navy SEAL who says he was the one who shot Osama bin Laden.

item.title: Who killed bin Laden?
item.description: CNN exclusive: A member of the secretive SEAL Team 6 tells CNN that a previous account of Osama bin Laden's shooting is completely wrong.

item.title: Same-sex marriage
item.description: The meaning of marriage and the implications of expanding that right to gays and lesbians is now squarely before the U.S. Supreme Court.

item.title: Pope support
item.description: Two priests say Pope Francis protected fellow Jesuits from the Argentinean military. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: GPS 'fingerprint'
item.description: Can you be identified only by where you take your phone? Yes, according to a new study.

item.title: Facebook futures?
item.description: Social media sites have become the global equivalent of the office watercooler, but could the buzz they generate be analyzed to predict real-world outcomes? Economist Noreena Hertz thinks so.

item.title: Teen tycoon
item.description: Silicon Valley giant Yahoo is turning to a 17-year-old to boost the company's mobile development by acquiring the teenager's tech start-up in a reported multi-million dollar deal.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Why oceans can't wait
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps into geothermal
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China's glamorous First Lady
item.description: China's new First Lady is poised to impress--and burnish China's image overseas.

item.title: Next stop Tanzania on Xi tour
item.description: CNN's David McKenzie explains why Chinese President Xi Jinping is stopping by Tanzania on his first foreign tour.

item.title: Xi starts foreign tour in Moscow
item.description: China's President Xi Jinping's choice of Moscow as his first foreign capital visit is being seen by analysts as a symbolic move that demonstrates the increasing interdependence of the one-time Cold War foes.

item.title: 2016: China to overtake U.S.
item.description: China is on track for a fourth consecutive decade of rapid growth and will overtake the US as the world's biggest economy in 2016 after accounting for price differences, according to a new report by the OECD.

item.title: China's workforce at a crossroads
item.description: China's extraordinary climb to the world's second largest economy was built on the back of Chinese workers, many of whom left rural farms to migrate for work in coastal factories.

item.title: Chinese bowl sells for $2.2 million
item.description: A rare Chinese bowl bought for about $3 from a yard sale in the U.S. sold for $2.2 million at an auction in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Pollution 'an economic concern'
item.description: CNN's Philippe Cousteau speaks about Chinese pollution and what can be done to clean up the environmental problems.

item.title: Hollywood dream lost in translation
item.description: When China's most successful homegrown movie went on international release last month, hopes were high that the slapstick comedy, which has drawn comparisons with "The Hangover," would blaze a trail for Chinese-language cinema.
